channel.title: Why is my code not working?
channel.description:
My code: [code]import java.applet.Applet; public class Panorama extends Applet { public void init( ) { // initialize System.out.println("In Panorama.init"); } } [/code] My HTML document: [code] Test Applet [/code] applet.html is in the same folder as Panorama.class. Running it in eclipse, it prints out "In Panorama.init", but when I run it in FireFox, it just gives me a red page, with a white rectangle in the top left. (The applet). The tutorial I read says this:
Activity: Basic applet and HTML using development tools Create a Panorama Applet class and HTML file. Override the init method and print out a trace message. Test and verify the message is printed. Here are the steps: 1. Create Panorama.java using a text editor. In the* file, add a public Panorama class and have it inherit from java.applet.Applet. In the* class, add an init method that takes no arguments and returns void. In in*it, issue System.out.println of "In Panorama.init". This provides a message when the method is invoked that traces the flow through the applet. Continue to add trace output to all methods you add to the applet. Save*the file and exit the editor. Your source code should look like this source code . 2. Compile using javac, and correct errors. 3. Create Panorama.html using a text editor. In Panorama.html, add an applet tag to invoke the Panorama.class with a width of 600 and a height of 130. Your file should look like this HTML file . 4. Save both your Java source file and HTML file in the same directory. 5. Run HTML using appletviewer. Did a blank frame appear, and did the line "In ..." appear separately on the console? If it did, quit or close the appletviewer and continue with the tutorial.

item.title: Why is my code not working?

in the html u forgot the .class

item.title: Why is my code not working?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Your code is working. That is what it is supposed to do.
The result is exactly the same at what the tutorial says it should be.

5. Run HTML using appletviewer. Did a blank frame appear, and did the line "In ..." appear separately on the console? If it did, quit or close the appletviewer and continue with the tutorial.
[quote="ranger squad, post:1, topic:306464"]but when I run it in FireFox, it just gives me a red page, with a white rectangle in the top left. (The applet).[/quote]

???

ps: You dont need applet viewer.

Read full topic

item.title: Why is my code not working?
item.dc:creator: @ranger_squad ranger squad
item.description:
@ranger_squad wrote:

My code:

[code]import java.applet.Applet;

public class Panorama extends Applet {
public void init( ) { // initialize
System.out.println(“In Panorama.init”);
}
}
[/code]

My HTML document:

[code]

Test Applet [/code]

applet.html is in the same folder as Panorama.class. Running it in eclipse, it prints out “In Panorama.init”, but when I run it in FireFox, it just gives me a red page, with a white rectangle in the top left. (The applet).

The tutorial I read says this:

Activity: Basic applet and HTML using development tools Create a Panorama Applet class and HTML file. Override the init method and print out a trace message. Test and verify the message is printed. Here are the steps: 1. Create Panorama.java using a text editor. In the* file, add a public Panorama class and have it inherit from java.applet.Applet. In the* class, add an init method that takes no arguments and returns void. In in*it, issue System.out.println of "In Panorama.init". This provides a message when the method is invoked that traces the flow through the applet. Continue to add trace output to all methods you add to the applet. Save*the file and exit the editor. Your source code should look like this source code . 2. Compile using javac, and correct errors. 3. Create Panorama.html using a text editor. In Panorama.html, add an applet tag to invoke the Panorama.class with a width of 600 and a height of 130. Your file should look like this HTML file . 4. Save both your Java source file and HTML file in the same directory. 5. Run HTML using appletviewer. Did a blank frame appear, and did the line "In ..." appear separately on the console? If it did, quit or close the appletviewer and continue with the tutorial.
